greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T(n,k), n>=0, 0<=k<=n, read by rows: T(n,k) = number of simple graphs on n labeled nodes with k edges where each maximally connected subgraph is either a tree or a cycle.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..140, flattened
Index entries for sequences related to trees
example: T(4,3) = 20, because there are 20 simple graphs on 4 labeled nodes with 3 edges, where each maximally connected subgraph is either a tree or a cycle, 16 of these graphs consist of a single tree with 4 nodes and 4 consist of a cycle with 3 and a tree with 1 node:
maple: f:= proc(n,k) option remember; local j; if k=0 then 1 elif k<0 or n<=k then 0 elif k=n-1 then n^(n-2) else add(binomial(n-1,j) *f(j+1,j) *f(n-1-j,k-j), j=0..k) fi end:
c:= proc(n,k) option remember; local i,j; if k=0 then 1 elif k<0 or n<k then 0 else c(n-1,k) +add(mul(n-i, i=1..j) *c(n-1-j, k-j-1), j=2..k)/2 fi end:
mathematica: f[n_, k_] := f[n, k] = Which[k == 0, 1, k<0 || n <= k, 0, k == n-1, n^(n-2), True, Sum[Binomial[n-1, j]*f[j+1, j]*f[n-1-j, k-j], {j, 0, k}]]; c[n_, k_] := c[n, k] = Which[k == 0, 1 , k<0 || n<k, 0, True, c[n-1, k] + Sum[Product[n-i, {i, 1, j}]*c[n-1-j, k-j-1], {j, 2, k}]/2]; T[n_, k_] := f[n, k] + Sum[Binomial[n, j]*f[n-j, k-j]*c[j, j], {j, 3, k}]; Table[Table[T[n, k], {k, 0, n}], {n, 0, 12}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 21 2014, translated from _Alois P. Heinz_'s Maple code *)
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Sep 12 2008
